an5.166:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi …pe…
an5.166:1.1.eng: There Venerable Sāriputta addressed the mendicants:

an5.166:1.2.pli: “idhāvuso, bhikkhu sīlasampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—
an5.166:1.2.eng: “Reverends, take a mendicant who is accomplished in ethics, immersion, and wisdom. They might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.

an5.166:1.4.pli: No ce diṭṭheva dhamme aññaṃ ārādheyya, atikkammeva kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ aññataraṃ manomayaṃ kāyaṃ upapanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—
an5.166:1.4.eng: If they don’t reach enlightenment in this very life, then, surpassing the company of gods that consume edible food, they’re reborn in a certain host of mind-made gods. There they might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.

an5.166:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā udāyī āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
an5.166:2.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Udāyī said to him,

an5.166:2.2.pli: “aṭṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, anavakāso yaṃ so bhikkhu atikkammeva kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ aññataraṃ manomayaṃ kāyaṃ upapanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—
an5.166:2.2.eng: “This is not possible, Reverend Sāriputta, it cannot happen!”

an5.166:3.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho …pe… tatiyampi kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:
an5.166:3.1.eng: But for a second … and a third time Sāriputta repeated his statement.

an5.166:3.2.pli: “idhāvuso, bhikkhu sīlasampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—

an5.166:3.4.pli: No ce diṭṭheva dhamme aññaṃ ārādheyya, atikkammeva kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ aññataraṃ manomayaṃ kāyaṃ upapanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—

an5.166:4.1.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā udāyī āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
an5.166:4.1.eng: And for a third time, Udāyī said to him,

an5.166:4.2.pli: “aṭṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, anavakāso yaṃ so bhikkhu atikkammeva kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ aññataraṃ manomayaṃ kāyaṃ upapanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—
an5.166:4.2.eng: “This is not possible, Reverend Sāriputta, it cannot happen!”

an5.166:5.2.pli: “yāvatatiyakampi kho me āyasmā udāyī paṭikkosati, na ca me koci bhikkhu anumodati.
an5.166:5.2.eng: “Venerable Udāyī disagrees with me three times, and not one mendicant agrees with me.

an5.166:5.3.eng: Why don’t I go to see the Buddha?”

an5.166:5.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
an5.166:5.4.eng: Then Sāriputta went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,

an5.166:5.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:

an5.166:5.6.pli: “idhāvuso, bhikkhu sīlasampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—
an5.166:5.6.eng: “Reverends, take a mendicant who is accomplished in ethics, immersion, and wisdom. They might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.

an5.166:5.8.pli: No ce diṭṭheva dhamme aññaṃ ārādheyya, atikkammeva kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ aññataraṃ manomayaṃ kāyaṃ upapanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—
an5.166:5.8.eng: If they don’t reach enlightenment in this very life, they’re reborn in the company of a certain host of mind-made gods, who surpass the gods that consume edible food. There they might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.

an5.166:6.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā udāyī āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
an5.166:6.1.eng: When he said this, Udāyī said to him,

an5.166:6.2.pli: “aṭṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, anavakāso yaṃ so bhikkhu atikkammeva kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ aññataraṃ manomayaṃ kāyaṃ upapanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—
an5.166:6.2.eng: “This is not possible, Reverend Sāriputta, it cannot happen!”

an5.166:7.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho …pe… tatiyampi kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:
an5.166:7.1.eng: But for a second … and a third time Sāriputta repeated his statement.

an5.166:7.2.pli: “idhāvuso, bhikkhu sīlasampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—

an5.166:7.4.pli: No ce diṭṭheva dhamme aññaṃ ārādheyya, atikkammeva kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ aññataraṃ manomayaṃ kāyaṃ upapanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—

an5.166:8.1.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā udāyī āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
an5.166:8.1.eng: And for a third time, Udāyī said to him,

an5.166:8.2.pli: “aṭṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, anavakāso yaṃ so bhikkhu atikkammeva kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ aññataraṃ manomayaṃ kāyaṃ upapanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—
an5.166:8.2.eng: “This is not possible, Reverend Sāriputta, it cannot happen!”

an5.166:9.2.pli: “bhagavatopi kho me sammukhā āyasmā udāyī yāvatatiyakaṃ paṭikkosati, na ca me koci bhikkhu anumodati.
an5.166:9.2.eng: “Even in front of the Buddha Venerable Udāyī disagrees with me three times, and not one mendicant agrees with me.

an5.166:9.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto tuṇhī ahosi.

an5.166:10.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ āmantesi:
an5.166:10.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Udāyī,

an5.166:10.2.pli: “kaṃ pana tvaṃ, udāyi, manomayaṃ kāyaṃ paccesī”ti?
an5.166:10.2.eng: “But Udāyī, do you believe in a mind-made body?”

an5.166:10.3.eng: “For those gods, sir, who are formless, made of perception.”

an5.166:10.4.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho tuyhaṃ, udāyi, bālassa abyattassa bhaṇitena.
an5.166:10.4.eng: “Udāyī, what has an incompetent fool like you got to say?

an5.166:10.5.eng: How on earth could you imagine you’ve got something worth saying!”

an5.166:11.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
an5.166:11.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,

an5.166:11.2.pli: “atthi nāma, ānanda, theraṃ bhikkhuṃ vihesiyamānaṃ ajjhupekkhissatha.
an5.166:11.2.eng: “Ānanda! How can you just watch while a senior mendicant is being harassed?

an5.166:11.3.pli: Na hi nāma, ānanda, kāruññampi bhavissati theramhi bhikkhumhi vihesiyamānamhī”ti.
an5.166:11.3.eng: Don’t you have any compassion for a senior mendicant who is being harassed?”

an5.166:12.1.eng: Then the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

an5.166:12.2.pli: “idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlasampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—
an5.166:12.2.eng: “Mendicants, take a mendicant who is accomplished in ethics, immersion, and wisdom. They might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.

an5.166:12.4.pli: No ce diṭṭheva dhamme aññaṃ ārādheyya, atikkammeva kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ aññataraṃ manomayaṃ kāyaṃ upapanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi vuṭṭhaheyyāpi—
an5.166:12.4.eng: If they don’t reach enlightenment in this very life, they’re reborn in the company of a certain host of mind-made gods, who surpass the gods that consume edible food. There they might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.

an5.166:12.6.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

an5.166:12.7.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ pāvisi.
an5.166:12.7.eng: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

an5.166:13.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando acirapakkantassa bhagavato yenāyasmā upavāṇo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ upavāṇaṃ etadavoca:
an5.166:13.1.eng: Then, not long after the Buddha had left, Venerable Ānanda went to Venerable Upavāṇa and said to him,

an5.166:13.2.eng: “Reverend Upavāṇa, they’ve been harassing other senior mendicants,

an5.166:13.4.pli: Anacchariyaṃ kho, panetaṃ āvuso upavāṇa, yaṃ bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito etadeva ārabbha udāhareyya yathā āyasmantaṃyevettha upavāṇaṃ paṭibhāseyya.
an5.166:13.4.eng: I wouldn’t be surprised if the Buddha brings this up when he comes out of retreat later this afternoon. He might even call upon Venerable Upavāṇa himself.

an5.166:13.5.eng: And right now I feel timid.”

an5.166:13.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena upaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ upavāṇaṃ etadavoca:
an5.166:13.6.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the assembly hall, where he sat on the seat spread out, and said to Upavāṇa,

an5.166:14.1.pli: “Katihi nu kho, upavāṇa, dhammehi samannāgato thero bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo cā”ti?
an5.166:14.1.eng: “Upavāṇa, how many qualities should a senior mendicant have to be dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired?”

an5.166:14.2.pli: “Pañcahi, bhante, dhammehi samannāgato thero bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo ca.
an5.166:14.2.eng: “Sir, a senior mendicant with five qualities is dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired.

an5.166:14.4.pli: Idha, bhante, thero bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu;
an5.166:14.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an5.166:14.5.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an5.166:14.6.pli: kalyāṇavāco hoti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā;
an5.166:14.6.eng: They’re a good speaker who enunciates well, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning.

an5.166:14.7.pli: catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī;
an5.166:14.7.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an5.166:14.8.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an5.166:14.9.pli: Imehi kho, bhante, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato thero bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo cā”ti.
an5.166:14.9.eng: A senior mendicant with these five qualities is dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired.”

an5.166:15.2.pli: Imehi kho, upavāṇa, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato thero bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo ca.
an5.166:15.2.eng: A senior mendicant with these five qualities is dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired.

an5.166:15.3.pli: Ime ce, upavāṇa, pañca dhammā therassa bhikkhuno na saṃvijjeyyuṃ, taṃ sabrahmacārī na sakkareyyuṃ na garuṃ kareyyuṃ na māneyyuṃ na pūjeyyuṃ khaṇḍiccena pāliccena valittacatāya.
an5.166:15.3.eng: If these five qualities are not found in a senior mendicant, why would their spiritual companions honor, respect, revere, or venerate them? Because of their broken teeth, gray hair, and wrinkled skin?

an5.166:15.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, upavāṇa, ime pañca dhammā therassa bhikkhuno saṃvijjanti, tasmā taṃ sabrahmacārī sakkaronti garuṃ karonti mānenti pūjentī”ti.
an5.166:15.4.eng: But since these five qualities are found in a senior mendicant, their spiritual companions honor, respect, revere, or venerate them.”

an5.167:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:

an5.167:1.2.pli: “codakena, āvuso, bhikkhunā paraṃ codetukāmena pañca dhamme ajjhattaṃ upaṭṭhāpetvā paro codetabbo.
an5.167:1.2.eng: “Reverends, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should first establish five things in themselves.

an5.167:2.2.eng: I will speak at the right time, not at the wrong time.

an5.167:2.3.eng: I will speak truthfully, not falsely.

an5.167:2.4.eng: I will speak gently, not harshly.

an5.167:2.5.eng: I will speak beneficially, not harmfully.

an5.167:2.6.eng: I will speak lovingly, not from secret hate.

an5.167:2.7.pli: Codakena, āvuso, bhikkhunā paraṃ codetukāmena ime pañca dhamme ajjhattaṃ upaṭṭhāpetvā paro codetabbo.
an5.167:2.7.eng: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should first establish these five things in themselves.

an5.167:3.1.pli: Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ passāmi akālena codiyamānaṃ no kālena kupitaṃ, abhūtena codiyamānaṃ no bhūtena kupitaṃ, pharusena codiyamānaṃ no saṇhena kupitaṃ, anatthasaṃhitena codiyamānaṃ no atthasaṃhitena kupitaṃ, dosantarena codiyamānaṃ no mettacittena kupitaṃ.
an5.167:3.1.eng: Take a case where I see a certain individual being accused at the wrong time, not being disturbed at the right time. They’re accused falsely, not disturbed truthfully. They’re accused harshly, not disturbed gently. They’re accused harmfully, not disturbed beneficially. They’re accused with secret hate, not disturbed lovingly.

an5.167:4.1.pli: Adhammacuditassa, āvuso, bhikkhuno pañcahākārehi avippaṭisāro upadahātabbo:
an5.167:4.1.eng: The mendicant who is accused improperly should be reassured in five ways.

an5.167:4.2.pli: ‘akālenāyasmā cudito no kālena, alaṃ te avippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:4.2.eng: ‘Venerable, you were accused at the wrong time, not at the right time. There’s no need for you to feel remorse.

an5.167:4.3.pli: abhūtenāyasmā cudito no bhūtena, alaṃ te avippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:4.3.eng: You were accused falsely, not truthfully. …

an5.167:4.4.pli: pharusenāyasmā cudito no saṇhena, alaṃ te avippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:4.4.eng: You were accused harshly, not gently. …

an5.167:4.5.pli: anatthasaṃhitenāyasmā cudito no atthasaṃhitena, alaṃ te avippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:4.5.eng: You were accused harmfully, not beneficially. …

an5.167:4.6.pli: dosantarenāyasmā cudito no mettacittena, alaṃ te avippaṭisārāyā’ti.
an5.167:4.6.eng: You were accused with secret hate, not lovingly. There’s no need for you to feel remorse.’

an5.167:4.7.pli: Adhammacuditassa, āvuso, bhikkhuno imehi pañcahākārehi avippaṭisāro upadahātabbo.
an5.167:4.7.eng: A mendicant who is accused improperly should be reassured in these five ways.

an5.167:5.1.pli: Adhammacodakassa, āvuso, bhikkhuno pañcahākārehi vippaṭisāro upadahātabbo:
an5.167:5.1.eng: The mendicant who makes improper accusations should be chastened in five ways.

an5.167:5.2.pli: ‘akālena te, āvuso, codito no kālena, alaṃ te vippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:5.2.eng: ‘Reverend, you made an accusation at the wrong time, not at the right time. There’s a reason for you to feel remorse.

an5.167:5.3.pli: abhūtena te, āvuso, codito no bhūtena, alaṃ te vippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:5.3.eng: You made an accusation falsely, not truthfully. …

an5.167:5.4.pli: pharusena te, āvuso, codito no saṇhena, alaṃ te vippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:5.4.eng: You made an accusation harshly, not gently. …

an5.167:5.5.pli: anatthasaṃhitena te, āvuso, codito no atthasaṃhitena, alaṃ te vippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:5.5.eng: You made an accusation harmfully, not beneficially. …

an5.167:5.6.pli: dosantarena te, āvuso, codito no mettacittena, alaṃ te vippaṭisārāyā’ti.
an5.167:5.6.eng: You made an accusation with secret hate, not lovingly. There’s a reason for you to feel remorse.’

an5.167:5.7.pli: Adhammacodakassa, āvuso, bhikkhuno imehi pañcahākārehi vippaṭisāro upadahātabbo.
an5.167:5.7.eng: The mendicant who makes improper accusations should be chastened in these five ways.

an5.167:5.9.pli: Yathā na aññopi bhikkhu abhūtena codetabbaṃ maññeyyāti.
an5.167:5.9.eng: So that another mendicant wouldn’t think to make a false accusation.

an5.167:6.1.pli: Idha panāhaṃ, āvuso, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ passāmi kālena codiyamānaṃ no akālena kupitaṃ, bhūtena codiyamānaṃ no abhūtena kupitaṃ, saṇhena codiyamānaṃ no pharusena kupitaṃ, atthasaṃhitena codiyamānaṃ no anatthasaṃhitena kupitaṃ, mettacittena codiyamānaṃ no dosantarena kupitaṃ.
an5.167:6.1.eng: Take a case where I see a certain individual being accused at the right time, not being disturbed at the wrong time. They’re accused truthfully, not disturbed falsely. They’re accused gently, not disturbed harshly. They’re accused beneficially, not disturbed harmfully. They’re accused lovingly, not disturbed with secret hate.

an5.167:7.1.pli: Dhammacuditassa, āvuso, bhikkhuno pañcahākārehi vippaṭisāro upadahātabbo:
an5.167:7.1.eng: The mendicant who is accused properly should be chastened in five ways.

an5.167:7.2.pli: ‘kālenāyasmā cudito no akālena, alaṃ te vippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:7.2.eng: ‘Venerable, you were accused at the right time, not at the wrong time. There’s a reason for you to feel remorse.

an5.167:7.3.pli: bhūtenāyasmā cudito no abhūtena, alaṃ te vippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:7.3.eng: You were accused truthfully, not falsely. …

an5.167:7.4.pli: saṇhenāyasmā cudito no pharusena, alaṃ te vippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:7.4.eng: You were accused gently, not harshly. …

an5.167:7.5.pli: atthasaṃhitenāyasmā cudito no anatthasaṃhitena, alaṃ te vippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:7.5.eng: You were accused beneficially, not harmfully. …

an5.167:7.6.pli: mettacittenāyasmā cudito no dosantarena, alaṃ te vippaṭisārāyā’ti.
an5.167:7.6.eng: You were accused lovingly, not with secret hate. There’s a reason for you to feel remorse.’

an5.167:7.7.pli: Dhammacuditassa, āvuso, bhikkhuno imehi pañcahākārehi vippaṭisāro upadahātabbo.
an5.167:7.7.eng: The mendicant who is accused properly should be chastened in these five ways.

an5.167:8.1.pli: Dhammacodakassa, āvuso, bhikkhuno pañcahākārehi avippaṭisāro upadahātabbo:
an5.167:8.1.eng: The mendicant who makes proper accusations should be reassured in five ways.

an5.167:8.2.pli: ‘kālena te, āvuso, codito no akālena, alaṃ te avippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:8.2.eng: ‘Reverend, you made an accusation at the right time, not at the wrong time. There’s no need for you to feel remorse.

an5.167:8.3.pli: bhūtena te, āvuso, codito no abhūtena, alaṃ te avippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:8.3.eng: You made an accusation truthfully, not falsely. …

an5.167:8.4.pli: saṇhena te, āvuso, codito no pharusena, alaṃ te avippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:8.4.eng: You made an accusation gently, not harshly. …

an5.167:8.5.pli: atthasaṃhitena te, āvuso, codito no anatthasaṃhitena, alaṃ te avippaṭisārāya;
an5.167:8.5.eng: You made an accusation beneficially, not harmfully. …

an5.167:8.6.pli: mettacittena te, āvuso, codito no dosantarena, alaṃ te avippaṭisārāyā’ti.
an5.167:8.6.eng: You made an accusation lovingly, not with secret hate. There’s no need for you to feel remorse.’

an5.167:8.7.pli: Dhammacodakassa, āvuso, bhikkhuno imehi pañcahākārehi avippaṭisāro upadahātabbo.
an5.167:8.7.eng: The mendicant who makes proper accusations should be reassured in these five ways.

an5.167:8.9.pli: Yathā aññopi bhikkhu bhūtena coditabbaṃ maññeyyāti.
an5.167:8.9.eng: So that another mendicant would think to make a true accusation.

an5.167:9.1.pli: Cuditena, āvuso, puggalena dvīsu dhammesu patiṭṭhātabbaṃ—
an5.167:9.1.eng: An individual who is accused should ground themselves in two things:

an5.167:9.3.pli: Mañcepi, āvuso, pare codeyyuṃ kālena vā akālena vā bhūtena vā abhūtena vā saṇhena vā pharusena vā atthasaṃhitena vā anatthasaṃhitena vā mettacittā vā dosantarā vā, ahampi dvīsuyeva dhammesu patiṭṭhaheyyaṃ—
an5.167:9.3.eng: Even if others accuse me—at the right time or the wrong time, truthfully or falsely, gently or harshly, beneficially or harmfully, lovingly or with secret hate—I will still ground myself in two things:

an5.167:9.6.eng: that quality is found in me, I will tell them that it is.

an5.167:9.9.eng: that quality is not found in me, I will tell them that it is not.”

an5.167:10.1.pli: “Evampi kho te, sāriputta, vuccamānā atha ca panidhekacce moghapurisā na padakkhiṇaṃ gaṇhantī”ti.
an5.167:10.1.eng: “Even when you speak like this, Sāriputta, there are still some futile people here who do not respectfully take it up.”

an5.167:11.1.pli: “Ye te, bhante, puggalā assaddhā jīvikatthā na saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā saṭhā māyāvino ketabino uddhatā unnaḷā capalā mukharā vikiṇṇavācā indriyesu aguttadvārā bhojane amattaññuno jāgariyaṃ ananuyuttā sāmaññe anapekkhavanto sikkhāya na tibbagāravā bāhulikā sāthalikā okkamane pubbaṅgamā paviveke nikkhittadhurā kusītā hīnavīriyā muṭṭhassatino asampajānā asamāhitā vibbhantacittā duppaññā eḷamūgā, te mayā evaṃ vuccamānā na padakkhiṇaṃ gaṇhanti.
an5.167:11.1.eng: “Sir, there are those faithless individuals who went forth from the lay life to homelessness not out of faith but to earn a livelihood. They’re devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued. They do not guard their sense doors or eat in moderation, and they are not dedicated to wakefulness. They don’t care about the ascetic life, and don’t keenly respect the training. They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, lazy, and lacking energy. They’re unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds, witless and idiotic. When I speak to them like this, they don’t respectfully take it up.

an5.167:12.1.pli: Ye pana te, bhante, kulaputtā saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā asaṭhā amāyāvino aketabino anuddhatā anunnaḷā acapalā amukharā avikiṇṇavācā indriyesu guttadvārā bhojane mattaññuno jāgariyaṃ anuyuttā sāmaññe apekkhavanto sikkhāya tibbagāravā na bāhulikā na sāthalikā okkamane nikkhittadhurā paviveke pubbaṅgamā āraddhavīriyā pahitattā upaṭṭhitassatino sampajānā samāhitā ekaggacittā paññavanto aneḷamūgā, te mayā evaṃ vuccamānā padakkhiṇaṃ gaṇhantī”ti.
an5.167:12.1.eng: Sir, there are those gentlemen who went forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith. They’re not devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re not restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued. They guard their sense doors and eat in moderation, and they are dedicated to wakefulness. They care about the ascetic life, and keenly respect the training. They’re not indulgent or slack, nor are they leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion. They’re energetic and determined. They’re mindful, with situational awareness, immersion, and unified minds; wise and clever. When I speak to them like this, they do respectfully take it up.”

an5.167:13.1.pli: “Ye te, sāriputta, puggalā assaddhā jīvikatthā na saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā saṭhā māyāvino ketabino uddhatā unnaḷā capalā mukharā vikiṇṇavācā indriyesu aguttadvārā bhojane amattaññuno jāgariyaṃ ananuyuttā sāmaññe anapekkhavanto sikkhāya na tibbagāravā bāhulikā sāthalikā okkamane pubbaṅgamā paviveke nikkhittadhurā kusītā hīnavīriyā muṭṭhassatino asampajānā asamāhitā vibbhantacittā duppaññā eḷamūgā, tiṭṭhantu te.
an5.167:13.1.eng: “Sāriputta, those faithless individuals who went forth from the lay life to homelessness not out of faith but to earn a livelihood … Leave them be.

an5.167:14.1.pli: Ye pana te, sāriputta, kulaputtā saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā asaṭhā amāyāvino aketabino anuddhatā anunnaḷā acapalā amukharā avikiṇṇavācā indriyesu guttadvārā bhojane mattaññuno jāgariyaṃ anuyuttā sāmaññe apekkhavanto sikkhāya tibbagāravā na bāhulikā na sāthalikā okkamane nikkhittadhurā paviveke pubbaṅgamā āraddhavīriyā pahitattā upaṭṭhitassatino sampajānā samāhitā ekaggacittā paññavanto aneḷamūgā, te tvaṃ, sāriputta, vadeyyāsi.
an5.167:14.1.eng: But those gentlemen who went forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith … You should speak to them.

an5.167:14.2.eng: Sāriputta, you should advise your spiritual companions!

an5.167:14.3.eng: You should instruct your spiritual companions!

an5.167:14.4.eng: Thinking: ‘I will draw my spiritual companions away from false teachings and ground them in true teachings.’

an5.168:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:
an5.168:1.1.eng: There Venerable Sāriputta addressed the mendicants:

an5.168:1.2.eng: “Reverends, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for right immersion.

an5.168:1.3.pli: sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an5.168:1.3.eng: When there is no right immersion, one who lacks right immersion has destroyed a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an5.168:1.4.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane asati yathābhūtañāṇadassanavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an5.168:1.4.eng: When there is no true knowledge and vision, one who lacks true knowledge and vision has destroyed a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an5.168:1.5.pli: nibbidāvirāge asati nibbidāvirāgavipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an5.168:1.5.eng: When there is no disillusionment and dispassion, one who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.168:1.6.eng: Suppose there was a tree that lacked branches and foliage.

an5.168:1.7.pli: Tassa papaṭikāpi na pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi pheggupi sāropi na pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an5.168:1.7.eng: Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would not grow to fullness.

an5.168:1.8.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, dussīlassa sīlavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti sammāsamādhi;
an5.168:1.8.eng: In the same way, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for right immersion.

an5.168:1.9.pli: sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an5.168:1.9.eng: When there is no right immersion, one who lacks right immersion has destroyed a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an5.168:1.10.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane asati yathābhūtañāṇadassanavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an5.168:1.10.eng: When there is no true knowledge and vision, one who lacks true knowledge and vision has destroyed a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an5.168:1.11.pli: nibbidāvirāge asati nibbidāvirāgavipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an5.168:1.11.eng: When there is no disillusionment and dispassion, one who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.168:2.1.pli: Sīlavato, āvuso, sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti sammāsamādhi;
an5.168:2.1.eng: An ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for right immersion.

an5.168:2.2.pli: sammāsamādhimhi sati sammāsamādhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an5.168:2.2.eng: When there is right immersion, one who has fulfilled right immersion has fulfilled a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an5.168:2.3.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane sati yathābhūtañāṇadassanasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an5.168:2.3.eng: When there is true knowledge and vision, one who has fulfilled true knowledge and vision has fulfilled a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an5.168:2.4.pli: nibbidāvirāge sati nibbidāvirāgasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an5.168:2.4.eng: When there is disillusionment and dispassion, one who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.168:2.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, rukkho, sākhāpalāsasampanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi pheggupi sāropi pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an5.168:2.5.eng: Suppose there was a tree that was complete with branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would grow to fullness.

an5.168:2.6.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, sīlavato sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti sammāsamādhi;
an5.168:2.6.eng: In the same way, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for right immersion.

an5.168:2.7.pli: sammāsamādhimhi sati sammāsamādhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an5.168:2.7.eng: When there is right immersion, one who has fulfilled right immersion has fulfilled a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an5.168:2.8.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane sati yathābhūtañāṇadassanasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an5.168:2.8.eng: When there is true knowledge and vision, one who has fulfilled true knowledge and vision has fulfilled a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an5.168:2.9.pli: nibbidāvirāge sati nibbidāvirāgasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanan”ti.
an5.168:2.9.eng: When there is disillusionment and dispassion, one who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.”

an5.169:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
an5.169:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

an5.169:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
an5.169:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to him:

an5.169:2.1.pli: “Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu khippanisanti ca hoti, kusalesu dhammesu suggahitaggāhī ca, bahuñca gaṇhāti, gahitañcassa nappamussatī”ti?
an5.169:2.1.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, how are we to define a mendicant who is quick-witted when it comes to skillful teachings, who learns well, learns much, and does not forget what they’ve learned?”

an5.169:2.3.eng: Why don’t you clarify this yourself?”

an5.169:2.4.pli: “Tenahāvuso sāriputta, suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
an5.169:2.4.eng: “Well then, Reverend Sāriputta, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an5.169:2.5.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmato ānandassa paccassosi.

an5.169:3.1.pli: “Idhāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu atthakusalo ca hoti, dhammakusalo ca, byañjanakusalo ca, niruttikusalo ca, pubbāparakusalo ca.
an5.169:3.1.eng: “It’s when a mendicant is skilled in the meaning, skilled in the teaching, skilled in definition, skilled in phrasing, and skilled in sequence.

an5.169:3.2.pli: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu khippanisanti ca hoti kusalesu dhammesu, suggahitaggāhī ca, bahuñca gaṇhāti, gahitañcassa nappamussatī”ti.
an5.169:3.2.eng: That is how to define a mendicant who is quick-witted when it comes to skillful teachings, who learns well, learns much, and does not forget what they’ve learned.”

an5.169:3.4.eng: How well this was said by Venerable Ānanda!

an5.169:3.5.pli: Imehi ca mayaṃ pañcahi dhammehi samannāgataṃ āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ dhārema:
an5.169:3.5.eng: And we will remember Venerable Ānanda as someone who possesses these five qualities:

an5.169:3.6.pli: ‘āyasmā ānando atthakusalo dhammakusalo byañjanakusalo niruttikusalo pubbāparakusalo’”ti.
an5.169:3.6.eng: ‘Reverend Ānanda is skilled in the meaning, skilled in the teaching, skilled in definition, skilled in phrasing, and skilled in sequence.’”

an5.17:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu attahitāya paṭipanno hoti, no parahitāya.
an5.17:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is practicing for their own welfare, but not that of others.

an5.17:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu attanā sīlasampanno hoti, no paraṃ sīlasampadāya samādapeti;
an5.17:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is personally accomplished in ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom. But they don’t encourage others in these qualities.

an5.17:1.4.pli: attanā samādhisampanno hoti, no paraṃ samādhisampadāya samādapeti;

an5.17:1.5.pli: attanā paññāsampanno hoti, no paraṃ paññāsampadāya samādapeti;

an5.17:1.6.pli: attanā vimuttisampanno hoti, no paraṃ vimuttisampadāya samādapeti;

an5.17:1.7.pli: attanā vimuttiñāṇadassanasampanno hoti, no paraṃ vimuttiñāṇadassanasampadāya samādapeti.

an5.17:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu attahitāya paṭipanno hoti, no parahitāyā”ti.
an5.17:1.8.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is practicing for their own welfare, but not that of others.”
